column1: The town of Clifton turned 100 years-old in 2017 but documented settlements in the area date back to 1679 when indigenous leader
column2: Captahem
column3: gifted a deed for 11
column4: 000 acres along the shores of the Passaic river to Hans Frederick. The modern name of "Clifton" was derived from the cliffs of Garrett Mountain which borders the Montclair Heights neighborhood in the western part of the city. Clifton was an agricultural hub and home to the U.S. Animal Quarantine Station was operated in Clifton by the United States Department of Agriculture starting in 1903. It was served by the Newark Branch of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad. It was the primary location on the East Coast where animals from poultry
column5: horses and cattle to zoo animals were held in quarantine after being brought into the United States to ensure that the animals were not infected with diseases that could be spread in the U.S. The station operated in Clifton until the late 1970s
column6: when the facility was relocated to Stewart International Airport.Although Clifton and surrounding towns have long converted from farmlands to suburban communities
column7: given their close proximity to Manhattan (Clifton is less than 15 miles directly west from Midtown)
column8: the town still boasts two small working farms that sell fresh organic vegetables in-season:

column1: Ploch's Farm: A family-run 15-acre farm since 1867.
City Green Farm Eco Center: An organic farm and 501(c)3 non-profit focused on promoting urban farming and education since 2004.

column1: The city of Clifton is governed under the 1923 Municipal Manager Law. The city is one of seven municipalities (of the 565) statewide governed under this form. The governing body is the City Council
column2: which is comprised of seven council members
column3: with all positions elected at-large on a non-partisan basis to concurrent four-terms of office as part of the November general election. The mayor is chosen by the City Council
column4: with the position traditionally given to the top vote getter in the previous election. Clifton's municipal elections had been held in May as required for municipalities conducting non-partisan elections. Following the passage of a state law in 2010 allowing non-partisan elections to be shifted to November
column5: Clifton voters were overwhelmingly in favor of the move in a non-binding referendum held in November 2013. On December 13
column9: to make the move to a November election binding
column10: which had the effect of extending the terms of all sitting council members by six months
column11: from June 30 to December 31. Officials cited increased voter participation and reduced costs as the justifications behind supporting the shift.As of 2020
column13: whose term of office ends December 31

column20: all of whom are serving concurrent terms of office that end on December 31

column1: If at any time a seat becomes vacant on the council
column2: it is filled by special election unless the vacancy occurs during a council election year. In the interim
column3: the council is allowed to appoint an interim councilperson to fill the seat until the election can take place (again
column4: except when the entire council is up for election); common practice is to nominate the eighth-place candidate from the previous election.

column4: Clifton High School is the largest single-facility high school in New Jersey; Elizabeth High School had more students

column7: was constructed at a cost of $17 million and opened in September 2009 to accommodate 540 of the school year's 850 incoming Freshman to alleviate overcrowding.Classical Academy Charter School of Clifton

column1: The Clifton Police Department is a full-service department and employs 159 sworn officers
column2: 20 public safety telecommunicators
column3: 12 civilians and 25 part-time special officers. The department is led by Chief Mark Centurione
column4: who was sworn into the position in May 2016.The Clifton Fire Department operates a fleet of five engines
column5: two ladders and two basic life support ambulances 24/7
column9: plus a haz-mat unit which are cross staffed. The department is led by Chief Frank S. Prezioso.

column1: Hatzolah of Passaic/Clifton EMS is a volunteer service that primarily covers the Passaic Park neighborhood of Passaic and parts of Clifton
column2: in addition to assisting local police and EMS when requested in other parts of the city. Hatzolah operates two ambulances strategically parked throughout the community with a third on standby and available to assist neighboring chapters such as Union City and Elizabeth.
